@mckinley Go supports a different way of conditionally compiling features in a codebase. Build flags. I‚Äôll bet I can fork gron and nuke the net/http code out and make it optional if that‚Äôs something you feel strongly about üòÖ

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª #randomQuestionsOfTheDay

@mckinley Agree on ‚Äúmicro dependencies‚Äù (NodeJS / NPM ecosystem is quite guilty of this); however I think this comes down to some level of ‚Äúgood practise‚Äù and ‚Äúgood code hygiene‚Äù ‚Äì I don‚Äôt necessarily think its the language‚Äôs fault or the tooling.

Re gron, to be fair, net/http (including client and server) are part of the Go standard library. I wouldn‚Äôt complain about that as an unnecessary dependency because it isn‚Äôt, maybe an unnecessary feature perhaps? üòÖ

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª It depends what you want to do , I use different languages for different use case :

@tkanos Whilst I respect your opinion, I strongly disagree with some of this. The only one is ‚ÄúPython for AI / ML‚Äù ‚Äì But that‚Äôs only because that‚Äôs how the scientific and machine learning community evolved. I‚Äôm actually aware of quite a number of good AI/ML and other libraries for Go. But in General AI/ML is quite hard to get into and requires special hardware too somewhat‚Ä¶

Java for big data pipelines is probably only because of Spark. To be fair I once did a lot of big data (multiple TB) of data processing in Python once upon a time. But if I were to do it again, I‚Äôd do it in Go.

NodeJS for Web is just umm well inexcusable üòÖ And if you believe the NodeJS original author/developer of the project, it was a mistake ü§£

content.html:
↳ In-reply-to ¬ª #randomQuestionsOfTheDay

@eaplmx Go. For the following reasons:

  • Go has a simple and easy learning curve with the right balance of ‚Äúlanguages‚Äù features
  • Go is a statically compiled language with good performace
  • Go has a great standard library
  • Go has great tooling
  • Go‚Äôs packaging (whilst some argue against) is actually pretty good
  • Go has first-class concurrency
  • Go‚Äôs concurrency model (CSP) lets you model concurrent programs linearly making concurrent programs easier to read
  • Go has a focus on readability
  • Go compiles insanely fast (if you avoid using CGO)
  • Go doesn‚Äôt support silly things like classes which is fucking great!
  • Go supports actual good reuse with interfaces and interface types
  • Go supports functional programming (yes it does!)
  • Go is awesome!

@eaplmx Go. For the following reasons:

Go has a simple and easy learning curve with the right balance of ‚Äúlanguages‚Äù features

Go is a statically compiled language with good performace

Go has a great standard library

Go has great tooling

Go‚Äôs packaging (whilst some argue against) is actually pretty good

Go has first-class concurrency

Go‚Äôs concurrency model (CSP) lets you model concurrent programs linearly making concurrent programs easier to read

Go has a focus on readability

Go compiles insanely fast (if you avoid using CGO)

Go doesn‚Äôt support silly things like classes which is fucking great!

Go supports actual good reuse with interfaces and interface types

Go supports functional programming (yes it does!)

Go is awesome!
